page.title: Euro gold and silver commemorative coins (Ireland)

revisions.rev:
{{Infobox country|maxwidth=250px|width=250px | native_name = {{lang|gle|''''Ãire''''}} | conventional_long_name = Ireland | image_map = Location Ireland EU Europe.png }} This article covers '''euro [[gold]] and [[silver]] commemorative coins''' issued by the [[Central Bank and Financial Services Authority of Ireland]]. It also covers rare cases of collectors coins (coins not planned for normal circulation) minted using other precious metals. It does not cover either the [[â¬2 commemorative coins|Irish â¬2 commemorative coins]] or the [[Commemorative coins of Ireland|Irish Pound commemorative coins]]. For euro gold and silver commemorative coins of other countries see [[Euro gold and silver commemorative coins]]. {{See also|Commemorative coins of Ireland}} ==2003 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Special Olympics World Summer Games |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' - | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Cu 750 Ni 250 | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 60,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' BU |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' - | align=center | '''Diameter:''' 28.4mm | align=center | '''Weight:''' 14.19g | align=center | '''Market Value:''' - |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Special Olympics World Summer Games |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer: V. Reverse: design features an image of Beckett with a scene of his most famous work âWaiting for Godotâ The coins were designed by Emmet Mullins who won a national design competition held in 2005.[http://www.centralbank.ie/frame_main.asp?pg=nws_article.asp%3FID%3D192&nv=nws_nav.asp Speech by governor John Hurley for launch of the Samuel Beckett coins]. Retrieved March 20th, 2010. The coin was part of the [[Europa coin programme]]'s [[Europa Coins 2006|2006 Theme ''Distinguished European figures'']]. |} ==2007 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Irelandâs influence on European Celtic culture |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Mary Gregoriy | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' B.H. Reverse: Four metamorphic figures in a cruciform arrangement in animated conversation with each figure holding in its hand an item that references a different aspect of how Ireland has influenced and inspired European [[Celtic nations|Celtic culture]]: literature, music, construction & new technology. rim- denomination (7 times) & [[Europa coin programme#Eurostar_logo|Eurostar]] mark (1 time). The coin was part of the [[Europa coin programme]]'s [[Europa Coins 2007|2007 Theme ''European Realisation'']]. The coins were launched at a reception in the National Museum of Ireland, Collins Barracks, hosted by the Governor of the Central Bank, John Hurley. |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|   |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Ivan MeÅ¡troviÄ's design |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Ivan MeÅ¡troviÄ & Damir MatauÅ¡iÄ' | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Croatian Monetary Institute |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬15 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 8,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 15.02.2007 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' 37.00mm | align=center | '''Weight:''' 24g | align=center | '''Original Value: â¬40.00

Reverse: stylized Brian Boru harp, female player to left behind - design submitted in 1927 by Ivan MeÅ¡troviÄ for use in the first coinage of the Irish Free State. Above: Ivan MeÅ¡troviÄ 1883 - 1962. The â¬15 coin has been produced in cooperation with the Croatian National Bank and commemorates the work of the Croatian sculptor, [[Ivan MeÅ¡troviÄ]]. |} ==2008 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| UNESCO Heritage Site of Skellig Michael |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Michael Guilfoyle | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Royal Dutch Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬20 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 999 | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 15,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 23.04.2008 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' 13.92mm | align=center | '''Weight:''' 1.244g | align=center | '''Market Value:''' |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| UNESCO Heritage Site of Skellig Michael |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Michael Guilfoyle | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Royal Dutch Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 25,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 23.04.2008 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' 38.61mm | align=center | '''Weight:''' 28.28g | align=center | '''Original Value: â¬36.00

This product has an individual issue limit of 10,000 pieces & a Double Proof Set limit of 5,000 pieces. The designer of the coin, Emmet Mullins, has created a modern interpretation of the Ploughman Design from the original banknotes. |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|   |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"| [[File:|160px]] [[File:|160px]] ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| G.A.A |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Michael Guilfoyle | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬15 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 10,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' ??.??.2009 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' 38.6 mm | align=center | '''Weight:''' 28.2 g | align=center | '''Market Value:''' |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| Obverse: Reverse: The coin Celebrates the 125TH Anniversary of the Gaelic Athletic Association (G.A.A.) |} ==2010 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| [[File:|160px]] ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Gaisce The Presidents Award |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Michael Guilfoyle | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Origination and production by The Royal Dutch Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬20 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 999 | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 10,000* | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 28.04.2010 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' 13.92mm | align=center | '''Weight:''' 1.00gms | align=center | '''Original Value: â¬58.00

Obverse: Traditionally depicting the 14 string Irish Harp modelled on the 'Brian BorÃº' harp in Trinity Colelge, Dublin. This harp has been used on Irish coins since 1928 and on this coin it is surrounded by a laurel wreath to reflect the prestigious nature of Gaisce - The Presidents Award. Reverse: Depicts Ãras an UachtarÃ¡in, the official residence of the President of Ireland, the patron of Gaisce. It also features some of thdiverse range of challenges that participants in the Award undertake. |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| [[File:|160px]] [[File:|160px]] ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| The Animals of Irish Coinage series |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Emmet Mullins | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Origination and production by The Royal Dutch Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬15 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 15,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 13.09.2010 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' 38.61mm | align=center | '''Weight:''' 28.28gms | align=center | '''Original Value: â¬36.00

Reverse: Features the harp and the year of date 2010. |} ==2011 coinage== {{expand section|date=March 2011}} {{see also|Europa Coins 2011}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== {{reflist}} # {{cite web | url=http://www.centralbank.ie/index.asp | title=The Central Bank & Financial Authority Of Ireland}} # {{cite web | url=http://www.emuenzen.de | title=emuenzen.de}} # {{cite web | url=http://www.starshop-forum.de | title=starshop-forum.de}} {{Euro coins (collectors edition)}} [[Category:Euro commemorative coins|Ireland]] [[Category:Coins of the Eurozone]] [[Category:Coins of the Republic of Ireland]] [[fr:PiÃ¨ces de collection en euro]] [[nl:Meerwaardeherdenkingsmunt]]
